title: Question Answering over Linked Data

author: Dennis Diefenbach, University Jean Monnet, St Etienne

segmentation: OK, hello everyone, I'm Dennis even back from University of Saint Etienne in France and I'm we participated to this challenge and in particularly we developed a question answering component which I would like to describe to you so.
Our question answering component works both on DPD and Vicki data, which is quite new development, so generally question answering system are focusing on one.
Knowledge graph and in fact our algorithm is also capable to be easily ported, be easily ported to other knowledge bases.
We are.

A tackling both full natural language question and keyword questions, and in particular keywords questions are so this the support of both is important cause generally real user don't ask a well formulated questions but some.
Noisy questions and is noisy.
Questions can be seen as an intermediate form of full natural language question and keyword questions, and we support a four different languages and we can answer.

We can generate sparkle queries of maximal two triple patterns which already allowed to answer quite a bit of questions, and we can generate both select and ask queries and select queries with counts.
So in particularly we do not support superlative or comparative.
Where you need order buys or limits.
We have integrated our component in corner ecorner reason infrastructure to share question answering resources and I would like to describe what are the benefits that this has.
So.
First of all, the question answering component can be accessed programmatically with via Restful APIs.
This one is a human readable version of one of these API's, so you can insert here the question.
You can select our question answering component for example this one for DPP genders.
For wiki data and then you run the question answering process.
Another advantage that we get.
Abide integration into Corner E is that we can combine our component with existing components.
In particularly, it can be combined with the speech recognition component so that you can first do the speech recognition and then execute the question answering component on it.
Or language detection module.
So language detection in question answering is a quite tricky task, so if anyone has good ideas on that I would be happy to.
Speak with him another.
Thing is that we have an interface for the evaluation available for QA.
That means that any other GNU user can come and evaluate our our component against new benchmarks.
That means we are transparent with respect to the Community, so the benchmark.
So you would select here the component we would generate one URL and you take this URL, you paste it in garbled for QA and you run your benchmark.
So it is easily this can be easily done.
Finally, we have a front end for it, which is called trill.
So when you ask, for example, which Sears near to Slovenia, you don't just get ugly UI or in Vicky data even worse, just a number.
But you get this sample of informations.
About
Valuation, so these are the numbers that we get on QLD 7 on the training data set.
The test set.
We do not know.
So we evaluated over the pedia in English, both on full and keyword questions.
So on full questions, we get an F measure of 0.51 on keyword question of zero point 39.
The dropdown is due to the fact that mostly in the keywords that are given by the QLD benchmark, it is not possible to decide if the question is an ASK query or not.
For example, the full network question is is Barack Obama Merritt with Michelle Obama and the keyword question is just Barack Obama Michelle Obama merit?
So you cannot decide what the user will really asked.
On Vicky data, we evaluate it on four different languages.
And we did both on keyword and full natural language questions.

And you'll see that it performs the best on French for keywords and in English for full natural language questions, and so the language that performs worse is Italian, and this is mainly due to the fact that in Wikipedia there are less state about Italian resources than in other languages.
So English, French and German are well.
Yeah, there are many, many lexicalization many names for the different resources.
And yeah, and the drop down from here, for example in French, so we get better performance when we go pass through keywords questions.
And this is due to the fact that generally the keyword questions in this data set are better formulated.
So for example, one question is when was the Battle of Waterloo and the keyword question is Battle of Waterloo, Dayton.
This is easier for us to tackle.
In fact, this was last slide.
Thank you very much for your attention.
If you are interested, we have a web demo under www.daqua.
DOT EU slash QA which is written.
Here and so if you visit other web service we are very happy we will collect your questions for Train.
Better our question answering system so we will lock your questions.
And otherwise we had the demo sessions.
We have two demos there, so we will also be very happy to welcome you there.
Thank you very much.
